Situation1: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I stared at the blueprints spread across my desk, red pen in hand, heart pounding. The hospital project was at a critical stage—today was the final inspection before construction resumed. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “We can’t afford a single oversight. Lives depend on this.” I knew I had to double-check every exit, every fire escape, every detail. But my phone buzzed, reminding me of my volunteer shift at the shelter. I was the only one with the keys, and people would already be lining up outside, waiting for warmth and food. If I was late, they’d be left in the cold. My mind raced, torn between the weight of responsibility as an architect—ensuring the safety of hundreds of future patients—and my commitment as a volunteer, not wanting to let down those who depended on me. The clock ticked louder, and I felt the pressure mounting, caught between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
